refsynopsisdiv.title: Synopsis

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The "GMarkup" parser is intended to parse a simple markup format that's a subset of XML. This is a small, efficient, easy-to-use parser. It should not be used if you expect to interoperate with other applications generating full-scale XML. However, it's very useful for application data files, config files, etc. where you know your application will be the only one writing the file. Full-scale XML parsers should be able to parse the subset used by GMarkup, so you can easily migrate to full-scale XML at a later time if the need arises.

GMarkup is not guaranteed to signal an error on all invalid XML; the parser may accept documents that an XML parser would not. However, invalid XML documents are not considered valid GMarkup documents.

Simplifications to XML include:
Only UTF-8 encoding is allowed.
No user-defined entities.
Processing instructions, comments and the doctype declaration are "passed through" but are not interpreted in any way.
No DTD or validation.

The markup format does support:
Elements
Attributes
5 standard entities: & < > " '
Character references
Sections marked as CDATA

refsect2.title: enum GMarkupError
refsect2.para: Error codes returned by markup parsing.

listitem.simpara: text being parsed was not valid UTF-8
document contained nothing, or only whitespace
document was ill-formed
error should be set by GMarkupParser functions; element wasn't known
error should be set by GMarkupParser functions; attribute wasn't known
error should be set by GMarkupParser functions; something was wrong with contents of the document, e.g. invalid attribute value

refsect2.title: G_MARKUP_ERROR
refsect2.para: Error domain for markup parsing. Errors in this domain will be from the GMarkupError enumeration. See GError for information on error domains.

refsect2.title: enum GMarkupParseFlags
refsect2.para: There are no flags right now. Pass "0" for the flags argument to all functions.

listitem.simpara: flag you should not use.

refsect2.title: struct GMarkupParseContext
refsect2.para: A parse context is used to parse a stream of bytes that you expect to contain marked-up text. See g_markup_parse_context_new(), GMarkupParser, and so on for more details.

refsect2.title: struct GMarkupParser
refsect2.para: Any of the fields in GMarkupParser can be NULL, in which case they will be ignored. Except for the error function, any of these callbacks can set an error; in particular the G_MARKUP_ERROR_UNKNOWN_ELEMENT, G_MARKUP_ERROR_UNKNOWN_ATTRIBUTE, and G_MARKUP_ERROR_INVALID_CONTENT errors are intended to be set from these callbacks. If you set an error from a callback, g_markup_parse_context_parse() will report that error back to its caller.

listitem.simpara: Callback to invoke when the opening tag of an element is seen.

varlistentry.term: void (*end_element) (GMarkupParseContext *context, const gchar *element_name, gpointer user_data, GError **error)

listitem.simpara: Callback to invoke when the closing tag of an element is seen

varlistentry.term: void (*text) (GMarkupParseContext *context, const gchar *text, gsize text_len, gpointer user_data, GError **error)

listitem.simpara: Callback to invoke when some text is seen (text is always inside an element)

varlistentry.term: void (*passthrough) (GMarkupParseContext *context, const gchar *passthrough_text, gsize text_len, gpointer user_data, GError **error)

listitem.simpara: Callback to invoke for comments, processing instructions and doctype declarations; if you're re-writing the parsed document, write the passthrough text back out in the same position
Callback to invoke when an error occurs

refsect2.title: g_markup_escape_text ()
refsect2.para: Escapes text so that the markup parser will parse it verbatim. Less than, greater than, ampersand, etc. are replaced with the corresponding entities. This function would typically be used when writing out a file to be parsed with the markup parser.
Note that this function doesn't protect whitespace and line endings from being processed according to the XML rules for normalization of line endings and attribute values.

listitem.simpara: some valid UTF-8 text
length of text in bytes
escaped text

refsect2.title: g_markup_printf_escaped ()
refsect2.para: Formats arguments according to format, escaping all string and character arguments in the fashion of g_markup_escape_text(). This is useful when you want to insert literal strings into XML-style markup output, without having to worry that the strings might themselves contain markup.

listitem.simpara: printf() style format string
the arguments to insert in the format string
newly allocated result from formatting operation. Free with g_free().

refsect2.title: g_markup_vprintf_escaped ()
refsect2.para: Formats the data in args according to format, escaping all string and character arguments in the fashion of g_markup_escape_text(). See g_markup_printf_escaped().

listitem.simpara: printf() style format string
variable argument list, similar to vprintf()
newly allocated result from formatting operation. Free with g_free().

refsect2.title: g_markup_parse_context_end_parse ()
refsect2.para: Signals to the GMarkupParseContext that all data has been fed into the parse context with g_markup_parse_context_parse(). This function reports an error if the document isn't complete, for example if elements are still open.

listitem.simpara: a GMarkupParseContext
return location for a GError
TRUE on success, FALSE if an error was set

refsect2.title: g_markup_parse_context_free ()
refsect2.para: Frees a GMarkupParseContext. Can't be called from inside one of the GMarkupParser functions.

listitem.simpara: a GMarkupParseContext

refsect2.title: g_markup_parse_context_get_position ()
refsect2.para: Retrieves the current line number and the number of the character on that line. Intended for use in error messages; there are no strict semantics for what constitutes the "current" line number other than "the best number we could come up with for error messages."

listitem.simpara: a GMarkupParseContext
return location for a line number, or NULL
return location for a char-on-line number, or NULL

refsect2.title: g_markup_parse_context_get_element ()
refsect2.para: Retrieves the name of the currently open element.

listitem.simpara: a GMarkupParseContext
the name of the currently open element, or NULL

refsect2.title: g_markup_parse_context_new ()
refsect2.programlisting: GMarkupParseContext* g_markup_parse_context_new (const GMarkupParser *parser, GMarkupParseFlags flags, gpointer user_data, GDestroyNotify user_data_dnotify);
refsect2.para: Creates a new parse context. A parse context is used to parse marked-up documents. You can feed any number of documents into a context, as long as no errors occur; once an error occurs, the parse context can't continue to parse text (you have to free it and create a new parse context).

listitem.simpara: a GMarkupParser
one or more GMarkupParseFlags
user data to pass to GMarkupParser functions
user data destroy notifier called when the parse context is freed
a new GMarkupParseContext

refsect2.title: g_markup_parse_context_parse ()
refsect2.programlisting: gboolean g_markup_parse_context_parse (GMarkupParseContext *context, const gchar *text, gssize text_len, GError **error);
refsect2.para: Feed some data to the GMarkupParseContext. The data need not be valid UTF-8; an error will be signaled if it's invalid. The data need not be an entire document; you can feed a document into the parser incrementally, via multiple calls to this function. Typically, as you receive data from a network connection or file, you feed each received chunk of data into this function, aborting the process if an error occurs. Once an error is reported, no further data may be fed to the GMarkupParseContext; all errors are fatal.

listitem.simpara: a GMarkupParseContext
chunk of text to parse
length of text in bytes
return location for a GError
FALSE if an error occurred, TRUE on success
